Triggering Event: She stumbled upon their wedding photo while sorting through old boxes in her new, sparsely furnished apartment. The once vibrant colors were now muted and faded, much like her feelings of love and hope that seemed like a distant dream. Her fingers traced the edges of the frame, the cool glass sending an icy chill up her spine. She hadn't realized she'd been holding her breath until it all came rushing out in a heavy sigh. The weight of her past felt heavier than ever as she placed the photo facedown on her desk, a silent vow to not let it consume her again.
Generated Assessment: What the fuck is wrong with me? I keep getting stuck on one fucking thing over and over again. It’s always the same shit. Why can’t I just move on? I’ve had enough of this toxic cycle. My life is so fucked up—my parents’ divorce, my abusive father, the constant stress, and now this stupid infatuation with him. I’m not even supposed to be here; I should be dead. I’ve lost count of how many times I’ve thought about ending it. But no, every time I think about killing myself, he comes back into my head and ruins everything. Every moment I spend thinking about him makes me hate him more. He doesn’t deserve me, but I can’t stop wanting him anyway. I don’t want to die, but I don’t know if I can live anymore. This isn’t fair at all. Life is so unfair, and I feel like I have nothing left to lose. I can’t take it anymore. I need to get away from him. I’m going to leave him. I swear, every time I try to tell myself I’ll stay for his kid, he’s there, reminding me that I shouldn’t care. I shouldn’t care. I won’t care. But what if I do? What if I really do care? No, no, no. That’s ridiculous. I’d never actually care. I mean, why would I? I already have everything I need right here.

Triggering Event: An empty canvas sat before him, mocking his once-vibrant creativity. His partner, hearing the soft click of the paintbrush hitting the floor, sighed from her seat nearby, engrossed in a book she'd read thrice before. He felt a familiar tightening in his chest as he glanced at the clock; another day wasted, another moment lost to this insidious hopelessness that had taken root within him.
Generated Assessment: My mind was already racing with possibilities - what if I'm just not cut out for art? What if my life is meant for something else? The thought sent me spiraling into thoughts of all the things I could be doing instead - learning a new skill, making money, moving away. It seemed like every choice was leading me further down a path I didn't want to take. But why couldn't I stop myself? Was it really because I lacked talent, or was there something more? It wasn’t until I saw how quickly my mind jumped to conclusions about everything—about my future, my worth, even the reason behind my sister’s depression—that I realized I was falling into a pattern. Every time I faced uncertainty, I started imagining all sorts of scenarios that fit into a narrative I’d created for myself. I wasn’t just thinking about what might happen next; I was convinced that I knew exactly what would come next, based on a story I'd built around my fears. I guess it's easier to think we're right when our minds are trying to make sense of things we can't control. My brain was spinning so fast, it made sense to jump to conclusions, especially when I felt trapped by them. Maybe I wasn’t just avoiding reality; maybe I was avoiding myself. But one thing was certain—it was hard to stop the cycle once it started, and it always left me feeling like I was running out of time. This emptiness wasn’t just about the blank canvas

Triggering Event: She opened the cupboard to retrieve her favorite spices, only to find his apron still hanging there, untouched since that last day in the kitchen together. The fabric bore a faint whiff of him, triggering a wave of grief so intense she had to lean against the counter to keep from collapsing.

Maybe he needs some time to figure himself out before he can face me again. But why does he have to make it so hard? Why can't he just tell me where he's going instead of leaving me with nothing but confusion and anger? And why does he get to be the one walking

Triggering Event: "Upon arriving home, he found the sink filled with unwashed dishes, despite his partner's promise to handle them after breakfast."
Generated Assessment: You're so lazy. You don't even bother washing the dishes like you promised. And now it's 4 pm already? What kind of relationship is this? Just because we didn't have plans today doesn't mean you get off scot-free. If you were going to do something, you'd at least be honest about it. But no, instead, you just leave me to deal with your dirty work again. Do you think I'm too stupid to notice that you never actually did anything around here? It's always the same thing: you make promises, then forget all about them, leaving me to pick up the pieces. This isn't how relationships work. Either you put in the effort or you shouldn't expect us to share responsibilities. But no, you keep taking advantage of me, expecting everything to fall into place magically. Well, let me tell you, it won't work out this way forever. You need to step up and take responsibility for your actions. Otherwise, things are going to blow up in your face. And when they do, don't come crying to me saying you didn't know what was coming. You always seem to act surprised when reality hits you right between the eyes. Triggering Event: She noticed him across the lab, laughing with their former supervisor. The same man who had praised her work yet signed off on her divorce papers, claiming she was too "absent-minded" in their marriage. She felt a familiar heat rise within her, a hatred that was no longer just an ember but a roaring flame. Her grip tightened around the beaker in her hand, the glass creaking under pressure as she struggled to maintain control.
Generated Assessment: She couldn't help but feel like his eyes were mocking her - daring her to acknowledge his presence. It wasn't the first time he'd crossed paths with her, but this encounter felt different. Maybe it was the way he smiled at her, the air thickening between them like a challenge. He seemed so confident, so at ease in her space, it made her skin crawl. Every step he took closer to her was like a betrayal, as if he was trying to remind her of the past - of how much he'd hurt her. She could almost smell the stench of his lies, the deceit that had marred their relationship. But what really got her blood boiling was that he hadn't even apologized for signing those divorce papers. He'd never acknowledged his part in ending their life together, and now he was pretending everything was fine? His laughter was like nails on a chalkboard, making her want to scream from the inside out. She knew she shouldn't let him get under her skin, but it was hard when every glance felt like a personal attack.

Triggering Event: "While grading papers at home, he notices a student's essay mocking his late wife's favorite book."
Generated Assessment: **I'm so fucking bummed out right now!** I was just sitting there grading some papers when this kid comes to me and says something like, "Hey, your wife's favorite book is such an ass-hole." And I just about lost it. I mean, I know she loved reading and all, but come on! It's not even funny! It's like, they're trying to make me feel bad for her because I'm dead. Like, what? That's so fucked up! I thought maybe it was one time thing, but nope, every single paper I graded had some stupid joke about my wife. And you know what really gets me? The fact that it's been going on for weeks. I've tried talking to him, asking him to stop, but he just gives these weird looks like he's not even listening. He's just saying whatever he thinks will get a laugh from everyone else, and honestly, it's kind of messed up. I don't understand why he's doing this. I guess I just assumed... well, actually, I didn't think much about it at first. But then I started thinking, **Maybe he's just making fun of me because he knows how much I loved that book. Maybe he thinks it's funny to see me upset over something like that.** But that doesn't make sense. I mean, why would he choose that specific book? And what makes me think he'd be laughing at me instead of

Triggering Event: She arrived home, her scrubs still stained from the day's shift, to find an unopened letter addressed to both of them. Her partner had left for work hours ago. She recognized the handwriting instantly - it was from her estranged sister whom she hadn't spoken to in years. As she picked up the envelope, she felt a familiar pang of shame, knowing what it might contain. The seal was unbroken, but the weight of its contents felt heavier than any patient she'd ever cared for.

The words are so vivid, they feel real. My heart sinks with every sentence, each one a punch to my chest. The pain is overwhelming, and I just want it to end. It's been 10 years since we last spoke, but this letter makes me feel like no time has passed at all. I'm not even sure why I opened it; maybe it was the way my hands shook when I picked it up, or how my eyes widened when I saw her name. Whatever it was, it's now too late. I know I shouldn't have looked inside, but I couldn’t help myself. The words are burning into my brain, echoing through every cell in my body. This isn’t just about her letter; it’s about everything that happened before. How could things have turned out differently? Why did life take us down such different paths? She wrote about our childhood, about the memories that once brought us together, now just make me feel guilty. I remember those days fondly, but now they’re tainted by the pain of what came after. Our parents were always distant, but I thought they loved us equally. Yet here I am, alone, while my brother lives his best life with his wife and kids. Even if he doesn’t know about me, I wish he knew. I

Triggering Event: A woman in her late twenties, still wearing her police uniform, sat alone at the bar nursing her drink. The other officers had left hours ago, but she stayed, drowning in the silence of her empty apartment. A familiar face walked in, a colleague who had known her husband. He approached, hesitated, then sat beside her. "I heard you pulled over young Tim today," he said, his voice gentle yet accusatory. She felt her cheeks flush with shame as she remembered the boy's tear-streaked face and pleading eyes. "He was speeding," she muttered, avoiding his gaze. The colleague nodded slowly, then left without another word. She watched him go, feeling the weight of her guilt grow heavier with each step he took away from her.
Generated Assessment: What the hell is wrong with me? I can't even get through a conversation about my husband's death without turning into a mess. It's been years since he died—yet every time someone mentions it, I feel like I'm drowning again. They say things like, “Oh, you must be so proud of your husband” or “We’re thinking of you,” but they don’t understand. To them, this isn’t about pride or being thought of; it’s just pain. But no matter how hard I try to explain, they always seem to think there’s more to the story than what I’m saying. They keep asking questions, like if I ever told him about something specific, if we talked about that particular thing before he died, if he knew something about our relationship that I didn’t know about him, if he ever lied to me about anything... Like, what exactly am I supposed to tell them? That every time I saw him, I felt guilty for not knowing everything about him? Or that I wish he’d never gotten sick because now I have to live with the pain of losing him? And don’t even get me started on the little things. When people say, “Your husband loved you,” they mean well, but they don’t realize it doesn’t make me feel better. In fact, it makes me feel worse. I remember all the times he would leave me notes, the way he used to hold my hand when we were walking, the way

Triggering Event: In the bustling kitchen of La Belle Époque, he meticulously arranged his signature amuse-bouche, a tradition for every dinner service since opening day. The young sous-chef, Thomas, approached him, "Chef, I've taken the liberty to adjust your recipe card for tonight's special." He felt a heat rise in his cheeks as he scanned the changes—his tried-and-true method replaced with modern techniques he barely understood. "I thought it could use some updating," Thomas added, not noticing or ignoring his flushed face. The kitchen filled with laughter and chatter, but to him, it was a deafening hum of humiliation.
